title.narrative: Secondment of SK to EU, Georgia, engagement

description.narrative:
As a supplement to our traditional contributions, based on partnerships with our Eastern partner countries, a limited part of the budget for the Neighbourhood programme, is allocated to secondments. This allows experts to be posted to international organisations and missions conducting activities relevant for the aims and goals set in the Neighbourhood programme.
The seconded National Expert, Anne Birgitte Hansen, for democracy, human rights and donor coordination, at the EU Delegation to Georgia, Tbilisi, will be working with some of the following priorities and programmes in Georgia.
The EU assistance priorities for Georgia centre on enhancing the country’s resilience through (1) resilient, sustainable and integrated economies; (2) accountable institutions, the rule of law and security; (3) environmental and climate resilience; (4) resilient digital transformation; and (5) resilient, fair and inclusive societies.
Enhancing the country’s democratic resilience is a priority of EU assistance under the forthcoming Multiannual Indicative Programme (2021-2027). The EU-Georgia Association Agreement requires Georgia to fulfil extensive commitments, including in the areas of democracy, human rights and the rule of law. Georgia’s National Human Rights Strategy together with the respective Action Plans provide an elaborated framework for implementation of Georgia's human rights agenda. EU support in Georgia focuses on democracy consolidation, strengthening the independence and accountability of the judiciary, child protection, as well as the promotion of human rights mechanisms, such as the Public Defender's Office or the Human Rights Secretariat under the Prime Minister's Office.
European Commission assistance to Georgia mainly takes the form of Annual Action Programmes under the Neighbourhood, Development and International Cooperation Instrument (NDICI). The indicative bilateral allocation for 2017-2020 was 371 to 453 million euros and the next multi-annual programming document for the period 2021-2027 is under preparation. A novelty under the new programming cycle is the development and implementation of Team Europe Initiatives, together with EU Member States, the European Investment Bank and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development. Close cooperation with EU Member States on the ground is taking place in the framework of “Working better together”, notably through joint analysis, joint messages and, where relevant and possible, joint implementation.
